SENT.plain: The central compensation of vestibular tonus imbalance due to unilateral peripheral vestibular lesions has been repeatedly documented
Little is known, however, about the central compensation of vestibular tonus imbalance due to central lesions

Dorsolateral medullary infarctions (Wallenberg's syndrome) typically cause a central vestibular tonus imbalance in the roll plane with deviations of perceived verticality and ipsiversive body lateropulsion

The course of normalisation of the tilts of subjective visual vertical (SVV) in 50 patients who had acute Wallenberg's syndrome were retrospectively compared with that in 50 patients with acute vestibular neuritis
The initial displacement of SVV was 9.8 degrees in Wallenberg's syndrome and 7 degrees in vestibular neuritis
The deviation of SVV significantly decreased over time within days to weeks in both groups
This finding shows that the time courses of the central compensation for dorsolateral medullary infarctions and peripheral vestibular lesions are similar
